is a small town in the Muskoka region of

.  Norman Bethune, the Canadian doctor who became famous in China for battlefield surgery, was born here, and is the town's most famous former citizen.  The town refers to itself as 'The Gateway to Muskoka' as is indicated on a large archway in the south-end of town.  The town is a drawing point for summer cottage season.  Many cottagers in the Muskokas use Gravenhurst for groceries and supplies and visit the town once or twice a week during cottage season.

Gravenhurst is located approximately 190 kilometers north of Toronto.  The easiest way to get to Gravenhurst is by automobile, as commercial bus service is limited and there are very few passenger trains to the area.  To reach Gravenhurst, take Highway 400 north from Toronto through

).  Proceed up Highway 11 and take Muskoka Road 169 - Bethune Drive (formerly Ontario Highway 169) right in to downtown.  Summer travel can be time consuming, as it is a popular tourist destination and the gateway to the Muskoka Lakes region.  The roads in Gravenhurst are well-maintained, so no need to worry about using a sport utility vehicle.
There is no commercial airport in or really anywhere near Gravenhurst, so the easiest way in for international travellers to access the region is to fly to

Pearson International Airport, rent a car and proceed north.  There is an airport in Bracebridge for propeller planes and/or private jets. Bracebridge is approximately 20 minutes by car away from Gravenhurst. If you're coming in from other domestic locations, it is possible to fly to
and drive in if Toronto doesn't appeal to you.
Gravenhurst is easily seen by foot.  No public transit system is currently in use.
There are private taxi companies offering local transportation. Intertown/city transport is by private bus companies. Casino Rama transportation provided by PMCL.
Private Carriers, Ontario Northland, PMCL, Hammond Transportation (705) 687-2301. Connections to major airports and Metropolitan Toronto.

value: content=Located in the south end of town. Great photo opportunity.
content=Daily fishing charters on Lake Muskoka, great family fun.

content= The Victorian church manse where this great Canadian was born in 1890 and where he lived for the first three years of his life. Bethune was a doctor who was an early proponent of universal health care, who was a key role-player in the development of humanitariran rights in China.

content= The recently built museum pays tribute to the history of a region that has shared its beauty and nature with generations. A great place to see the old wooden boats that at one time, were a common site on the great Muskoka lakes.
name=Grace and Speed - Muskoka Boat and Heritage Centre
content= One of Canada's Top 10 New Attractions of 2006
content=Training facility for provincial fire fighters. Has a small museum.
name=RMS Segwun and Wanda III (fully operational steamship cruises)

content=  Built in 1924, these small steamships are a wonderful throwback to a simpler time. At one point in time the Segwun was used to transport vacationers to their cottages, and currently offers tourists a chance to take a boat ride in to the past.

content= One of Muskoka's most significant landmarks is the heart of cultural activities, featuring both local and commercial entertainment year-round. The beautiful heritage theatre features excellent lighting and sound systems, a large stage with offstage storage areas, 338 comfortable upholstered theatre seats and the most up-to-date public safety systems available.

(Wednesday) - Muskoka Wharf, (705) 684-8731.  Showcases over 70 vendors with high quality fruits and vegetables, plants, organic produce, homemade goods, fresh honey, maple syrup, preserves, meat, fish, cheese more.  Local artisans sell carefully handcrafted jewellery, sewing, knitting, carvings, woodworking,  soap and fine art.  Shop at the market and enjoy a freshly-made crepe, sausage on a bun.
content=Only open from June through the first weekend in September.

content=A beautiful lakeside 5 bedroom, 4 bathroom cottage available to rent year-round in the Muskokas. Built-in Hot Tub open throughout the seasons. Surrounded by forest on 3 sides - a nature lovers paradise.

The wonderful thing about visiting  Muskoka is that there are plenty of small towns in the area to visit.
are all within a few minutes or 1-2 hours driving distance.

is close by if you're a visitor to the province coming in from Highway 17 to the north.  The region is rich with museums, shopping, and attractions.  For those who like to gamble, there is Casino Rama (located near the small town of Rama) near

.  Webers Burgers (go south 25-30 minutes drive on Highway 11) is an attraction unto itself with it's rail-car dining area and unique (to the region) overpass walkway.  And in Muskoka, one can always find a secluded lake to just sit and admire the scenery.
